text: I think it's close to about 200 and it's
been 45 years in the industry I don't
look back at the number of films I've
done I rather look forward to something
that may be happening in the years to
come hopefully so yes it's been very
exciting the journey and right now
promoting my film shamitabh which is due
for release on the 6th of February and
really very excited to be talking to you
we've been talking to a lot of young
people here through the course of today
and they've been talking about the
change in India and that change extends
just about everywhere including film the
types of films that are being made yes
indeed I think that with time morally
socially politically things change in
any country and having seen almost four
decades of it in my career in the film
industry I do notice many changes social
changes moral changes that have been
taking place and cinema has at least in
our country reflected at times what
society is doing what the morals are and
trying to make a comment or just living
up to expectations from the people of
the country that's interesting because
current Johari who of course you've made
many many films with he directed a short
film about a gay relationship now that's
a sort of film that you would perhaps
see in the UK or the u.s. just take me
through how bold is that for India and
Indian film India has always been
somewhat conservative in their outlook
and their thinking but I think with with
modern mediums of communication that
have come up in the past few years I
think India is exposed to a lot of stuff
that is happening in other parts of the
world almost instantly I would like to
believe that that has a lot to do with a
temperament with with a kind of
creativity that you're seeing in cinema
on television when we have 800
television channels in one country it is
very difficult not to notice content
that comes out
from all over the world or not be
impressed by it
now talking about change I read that you
would actually like people to stop using
that term Bollywood's tell me why what
would you prefer instead just call it
the Indian film industry because I think
that's a borrowed name we're okay with
what we do I don't see why it should be
I think it was just an expression that
came out from a smart journalist and now
it's in the Oxford Dictionary so it's
going to be there for eternity tell me
about this Obama visit you'll have been
watching closely we saw you singing the
national anthem
I mean how excited have you been well I
think the presence of the head of state
of one of the most powerful countries in
the world bodes well for India we enjoy
the friendship and the association as
much as politically the present
government does we hope that this
association fructifies into a great
amount of positivity there's been a lot
of excitement this is mr. Obama's second
visit to to India during one term of his
presidency and obviously it speaks a lot
for the association that he and mr.
Narendra Modi are honorable Prime
Minister have been having over the past
few days you do a lot of work on issues
like polio you do work on poverty I mean
it's interesting we've spent the day
here at Delhi University talking to
students they're very enthusiastic he's
exactly as you would expect but it is
you have to look at it and think it is a
privileged privileged position do you
ever look at wider education in India
and think there are huge inequalities
and we have to make more progress on
closing that gap I feel very honored
that I was appointed by the United
Nations on the polio campaign and we
worked for about eight years before we
could make India free of polio and I
feel very proud of the fact that we were
able to do that I'm also working now on
a campaign against safeguarding
tuberculosis we're going to be doing
another one for hepatitis I already do a
campaign on diabetes which actually
originates from from London the right
honourable Keith Vaz Member of
Parliament started this and I'm very
happy to be associated with him but yes
as far as education is concerned that's
been also a very important point for us
United Nations has also appointed me for
the girl child and we booked strenuously
I do believe that the latest campaign
that Prime Minister Nuri
begun beti bachao beti paja saved the
girl child and educator is very vital
for India I have always believed that
women form 50% of the strength of any
country and sooner or later I see this
speculating this thought percolating
into the rest of the country we have
given a lot of importance to women and
in my own profession if I may just look
back way back in the 60s when I began
they used to be just one lady on set
that was the chaperone with the leading
lady of a mother or sister or somebody
like that but now if you watch on our
sets there are women working behind the
camera there are assistant directors
they look after management they they
look after production they direct films
in the last few years we've had some
prominent women directors who have made
women oriented films and they've all
been very popular and very successful so
yes I do look upon the coming years to
be very progressive in this front just a
final thought about your new film it's
very interesting concept it's about a
mega famous film star but actually it's
an alcoholic who's dubbing all his voice
and it's his voice that he is famous for
in the conflicts between those two
that's a very interesting concept yes I
do believe that it it's a very unique
concept something that perhaps Indian
cinema has not seen before it's a very
interesting and very intelligent plot
it's a camel
it's a wasted wasted decrepit
alcoholic who's leading a very very
morose life and is brought together with
another person who he lends his voice to
because that's the quality that the
other person does not possess
and how the two combined together with
the help of a journalist to attain
success in life and then ego comes into
play and what transpires after that is
